questions.text: What is the difference between let, const, and var in JavaScript?
questions.sample_answer: let and const are block-scoped, while var is function-scoped. const cannot be reassigned, let can be reassigned, and var can be redeclared.

questions.text: Explain the concept of closures in JavaScript.
questions.sample_answer: A closure is a function that has access to variables in its outer scope, even after the outer function has returned.

questions.text: What are React hooks and why were they introduced?
questions.sample_answer: Hooks are functions that let you use state and lifecycle features in functional components. They were introduced to simplify component logic and enable code reuse.

questions.text: Explain the difference between useEffect and useLayoutEffect.
questions.sample_answer: useEffect runs after paint, useLayoutEffect runs synchronously after DOM mutations but before paint. Use useLayoutEffect when you need to measure DOM or prevent visual flicker.

questions.text: How would you optimize the performance of a React application?
questions.sample_answer: Use React.memo, useMemo, useCallback, code splitting, lazy loading, virtualization for long lists, and avoid unnecessary re-renders.

questions.text: What is the Virtual DOM and how does it work?
questions.sample_answer: Virtual DOM is a lightweight copy of the actual DOM. React compares it with the real DOM and only updates what changed, making updates efficient.

questions.text: Explain the CSS Box Model.
questions.sample_answer: The box model consists of content, padding, border, and margin. It defines how elements are sized and spaced on a page.

questions.text: What is the difference between Flexbox and CSS Grid?
questions.sample_answer: Flexbox is one-dimensional (row or column), Grid is two-dimensional (rows and columns). Use Flexbox for components, Grid for layouts.

questions.text: What are semantic HTML tags and why are they important?
questions.sample_answer: Semantic tags like header, nav, article give meaning to content. They improve accessibility, SEO, and code readability.

questions.text: Explain how you would implement server-side rendering in a React application.
questions.sample_answer: Use Next.js or implement custom SSR with Node.js. Render React components on the server, send HTML to client, then hydrate for interactivity.

questions.text: What is REST API and what are its principles?
questions.sample_answer: REST is an architectural style using HTTP methods. Principles include stateless communication, client-server separation, cacheability, and uniform interface.

questions.text: Explain the difference between SQL and NoSQL databases.
questions.sample_answer: SQL databases are relational with fixed schemas (MySQL, PostgreSQL). NoSQL are non-relational with flexible schemas (MongoDB, Redis). Choose based on data structure needs.

questions.text: What is middleware in Express.js or FastAPI?
questions.sample_answer: Middleware are functions that execute during request-response cycle. They can modify requests, responses, end cycles, or call next middleware.

questions.text: How would you design a scalable microservices architecture?
questions.sample_answer: Use API gateway, service discovery, load balancing, message queues, containerization (Docker), orchestration (Kubernetes), and implement circuit breakers.

questions.text: What is the purpose of environment variables?
questions.sample_answer: Environment variables store configuration separately from code. They manage secrets, API keys, and environment-specific settings securely.

questions.text: Explain JWT authentication and how it works.
questions.sample_answer: JWT (JSON Web Token) is a stateless authentication method. Server creates signed token with user data, client sends it with requests, server verifies signature.

questions.text: How would you handle database transactions and ensure ACID properties?
questions.sample_answer: Use database transactions with BEGIN, COMMIT, ROLLBACK. Ensure Atomicity (all or nothing), Consistency (valid state), Isolation (concurrent safety), Durability (permanent changes).

questions.text: What is caching and when would you use it?
questions.sample_answer: Caching stores frequently accessed data in fast storage (Redis, Memcached). Use for expensive queries, API responses, session data to improve performance.

questions.text: Explain the difference between an array and a linked list.
questions.sample_answer: Arrays have contiguous memory with O(1) access, fixed size. Linked lists have non-contiguous memory with O(n) access, dynamic size, efficient insertion/deletion.

questions.text: What is Big O notation and why is it important?
questions.sample_answer: Big O describes algorithm time/space complexity in worst case. It helps compare efficiency and scalability of different solutions.

questions.text: Explain how a hash table works and its time complexity.
questions.sample_answer: Hash table uses hash function to map keys to array indices. Average O(1) for insert/search/delete. Handles collisions with chaining or open addressing.

questions.text: Describe different tree traversal methods and their use cases.
questions.sample_answer: Inorder (left-root-right) for BST sorting, Preorder (root-left-right) for copying trees, Postorder (left-right-root) for deletion, Level-order for BFS.

questions.text: Explain dynamic programming and give an example.
questions.sample_answer: DP solves problems by breaking into subproblems and storing results. Example: Fibonacci with memoization reduces O(2^n) to O(n).

questions.text: What is the difference between BFS and DFS?
questions.sample_answer: BFS explores level by level using queue, finds shortest path. DFS explores depth-first using stack/recursion, uses less memory for deep graphs.

questions.text: Tell me about a time you faced a difficult challenge at work.
questions.sample_answer: Use STAR method: Situation (context), Task (responsibility), Action (steps taken), Result (outcome and learning).

questions.text: Describe a situation where you had to work with a difficult team member.
questions.sample_answer: Focus on communication, empathy, finding common ground, and achieving positive outcome despite challenges.

questions.text: Why do you want to work for our company?
questions.sample_answer: Research company values, products, culture. Connect your skills and goals with company mission. Show genuine interest.

questions.text: Tell me about a time you failed and what you learned from it.
questions.sample_answer: Be honest, show accountability, focus on lessons learned and how you improved. Demonstrate growth mindset.

questions.text: How do you handle tight deadlines and pressure?
questions.sample_answer: Discuss prioritization, time management, communication with stakeholders, staying calm, and delivering quality work under pressure.

questions.text: What are your greatest strengths?
questions.sample_answer: Choose 2-3 relevant strengths with specific examples. Connect to job requirements. Be authentic and confident.

questions.text: Describe a time when you had to learn a new technology quickly.
questions.sample_answer: Explain learning approach, resources used, challenges faced, and successful application. Show adaptability and learning agility.

questions.text: Tell me about a time you disagreed with your manager's decision.
questions.sample_answer: Show respect, explain how you presented alternative viewpoint professionally, outcome, and what you learned about communication.

questions.text: What is prop drilling and how can you avoid it?
questions.sample_answer: Prop drilling passes props through multiple levels. Avoid with Context API, Redux, or component composition patterns.

questions.text: Explain how you would implement code splitting in a React application.
questions.sample_answer: Use React.lazy() and Suspense for component-level splitting, dynamic imports for route-based splitting, and webpack for bundle optimization.

questions.text: What is the difference between controlled and uncontrolled components?
questions.sample_answer: Controlled components have form data handled by React state. Uncontrolled use refs and DOM handles data. Controlled gives more control.

questions.text: Explain event bubbling and event capturing in JavaScript.
questions.sample_answer: Bubbling: event propagates from target to root. Capturing: root to target. Use stopPropagation() to prevent bubbling.

questions.text: What are Web Workers and when would you use them?
questions.sample_answer: Web Workers run JavaScript in background threads. Use for heavy computations, data processing, or tasks that would block UI.

questions.text: How would you implement rate limiting in an API?
questions.sample_answer: Use token bucket or sliding window algorithm. Store counters in Redis. Return 429 status when limit exceeded. Consider per-user and global limits.

questions.text: Explain the difference between authentication and authorization.
questions.sample_answer: Authentication verifies identity (who you are). Authorization determines permissions (what you can do). Both are essential for security.

questions.text: How would you design a URL shortener service?
questions.sample_answer: Use base62 encoding for short URLs, hash table for mapping, database for persistence, caching for performance, and handle collisions.

questions.text: What is CORS and how do you handle it?
questions.sample_answer: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) allows controlled access to resources from different origins. Configure server headers or use proxy.

questions.text: Explain the difference between GET and POST requests.
questions.sample_answer: GET retrieves data, idempotent, cacheable, parameters in URL. POST sends data, not idempotent, not cached, data in body.

questions.text: Explain how to detect a cycle in a linked list.
questions.sample_answer: Use Floyd's cycle detection (tortoise and hare). Two pointers at different speeds. If they meet, cycle exists. Time O(n), Space O(1).

questions.text: What is a binary search tree and what are its properties?
questions.sample_answer: BST is a tree where left subtree < node < right subtree. Enables O(log n) search, insert, delete in balanced tree.

questions.text: Explain the difference between merge sort and quick sort.
questions.sample_answer: Merge sort: stable, O(n log n) always, O(n) space. Quick sort: unstable, O(n log n) average, O(nÂ²) worst, O(log n) space.

questions.text: How do you prioritize tasks when everything seems urgent?
questions.sample_answer: Use Eisenhower matrix (urgent/important), communicate with stakeholders, break down tasks, focus on impact, delegate when possible.

questions.text: Describe a time when you had to give constructive feedback to a colleague.
questions.sample_answer: Use specific examples, focus on behavior not person, be timely, offer solutions, follow up. Show empathy and professionalism.

questions.text: What motivates you in your work?
questions.sample_answer: Be authentic. Mention learning, impact, teamwork, challenges, or growth. Connect to role and company.

questions.text: Tell me about a time you had to make a decision without complete information.
questions.sample_answer: Explain situation, how you gathered available data, consulted others, made informed decision, and adapted as new information emerged.

questions.text: How do you stay updated with new technologies and industry trends?
questions.sample_answer: Mention blogs, podcasts, courses, conferences, side projects, open source contributions, and professional networks.
